concept.title: Useful gfsh Shell Variables
concept.shortdesc: You can use the built-in gfsh shell variables in scripts.

conbody.p: You can also use the set variable command to modify shell behavior or to define your own variables.
To see a list of all gfsh shell variables and their current values, use the following command:
To obtain the current value of an existing variable, use the following command syntax (the variable must be enclosed in braces):

row.entry: CLASSPATH of the gfsh JVM (read only).
Product directory where Pivotal has been installed (read only).
Host from which gfsh is started (read only).
Line separator (\ or ^) variable that you can use when writing gfsh scripts. (read only).
Number of items in the embedded collection of a result to be iterated Values: 1-100. Default value is 20.
Fetch size to be used while querying. Values: 0 - 2147483647. Default value is 1000.
Last command exit status. Similar to $? (Unix) and %errorlevel% (Windows). Values: 0 (successful), 1 (error), 2(crash) (read only).
Whether gfsh logging is enabled. Default: false (read only). You can enable gfsh logging by setting the gfsh.log-level Java system property to a supported Java log level.
Path and name of current gfsh log file (read only).
Current working directory where gfsh was launched (read only).
Toggle the display mode for returning query results. Values: table or catalog. Default value is table.
Whether the execution should be in quiet mode. Values (case insensitive): true, false. Default value is false.
Unix only. Set this variable to external to enable viewing of the output using the UNIX less command. Default value is basic (gfsh).
